comment: Zootopia is an animated movie that seems far more interested in making sure you understand its message than in trusting you to enjoy the story. From early on, the film’s allegory for racism is pushed so hard it stops being allegory and starts feeling like a checklist. Every conflict exists to reinforce the same point, and characters regularly pause the momentum to restate the moral in plain terms. There’s little room for subtext, ambiguity, or audience interpretation. If you somehow missed the message the first time, don’t worry—the movie will repeat it again, slower, and with emphasis. What’s frustrating is that the world-building and premise are genuinely clever. But instead of letting themes emerge naturally, the film insists on guiding your reaction at every step. By the second half, the messaging becomes so overt and self-satisfied that it actively hurts watchability. It’s not offensive. It’s exhausting. A movie that mistakes repetition for depth and sincerity for insight.

comment: ★★★★☆ Zootopia is that rare animated movie that works brilliantly as both a hilarious buddy-cop comedy for kids and a surprisingly sharp, layered allegory about prejudice, systemic bias, and the danger of fear-based politics for adults. The world-building is absolutely off the charts: a sprawling, fully realized metropolis where every district (from icy Tundratown to rainy Rainforest District) feels alive, detailed, and logically designed for animals of every size. The gag density is insane (the sloth DMV scene is still one of the funniest things ever animated), and the action sequences (especially the naturalist club chase and the climactic train fight) are genuinely thrilling. Judy Hopps is an all-timer protagonist: tiny, relentlessly optimistic, and forced to confront her own unconscious biases in ways that feel honest and earned. Nick Wilde’s slow journey from cynical hustler to proud cop is pure charm, and Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman have chemistry that leaps off the screen. Shakira’s "Try Everything" over the end credits still gives goosebumps every single time. It loses half a star only because the third-act "big twist" is a little convoluted and the villain’s motive feels a touch undercooked compared to the rest of the film’s nuance. Four stars: one for the laughs, one for the heart, one for the world you never want to leave, and one because it somehow made a story about predator-prey relations feel urgently relevant without ever preaching. Smart, gorgeous, endlessly rewatchable comfort food with a brain. 8/10. Welcome to Zootopia—population: one of the best animated movies of the 2010s. 🐰🦊🏙️❤️

The Lion King that's been my most favorite and top Disney movie of all time for many many years and still is I couldn't tell you how many times I watched that movie when I was a child and while I was growing up in my teens and adult years. Behind the scenes there are a lot of deleted scenes and scrapped ideas, including disagreements on who the main character was going to be. These disfunctions are well hidden for the most part, until the final 30 minutes. The movie suffers from tonal whiplash as they transition from one plot point to the other. Still a good time, the film just gets a heavy handed with their commentary towards the end. comment: The Best Film Of The Year, So Far. From the studio that brought you Tangled, Wreck-It Ralph, Frozen & Big Hero 6, Zootopia surfaces as a highly original, incredibly refreshing, thoroughly engaging, surprisingly timely & delightfully subversive beast fable about prejudice & stereotype that not only marks a new creative high for Disney but is arguably the finest film that this legendary animation studio has come up with in their Revival Era, so far. Set in a world inhabited by anthropomorphic animals, the story of Zootopia takes place in the titular metropolis and follows a bunny cop named Judy Hopps who, despite her par excellent performance in the class, is assigned parking duty by her superior. But when she volunteers to undertake a missing-predator case, she is given 48 hours to solve the mystery or resign, following which she blackmails a sly fox into helping her, and uncovers a sinister conspiracy. Co-directed by Byron Howard & Rich Moore, the duo put up an intriguing world on the screen that does have a fresh quality but there is still a deep sense of familiarity to it. However, where the two leave a lasting impression is in finding that perfect balance between its consistently gripping storyline & moments of pure hilarity. The writing staff also deserves a mention, for their screenplay brims with numerous pop culture references, parodies many renowned classics & handles its topical themes with care. The 3D animation is absolutely top-notch, for the images retain its crispness, clarity & vibrancy from beginning to end. The animators put up a vast number of characters on the screen, ranging from the largest elephant to the smallest shrew, yet they are all given a well-defined arc. Cinematography further enhances the overall look n feel of the story with its fluid camera-work, splendid use of colour palette & spot-on lighting. Editing provides just enough screen time to all the relevant characters while moving the plot forward at a blistering pace. The cast is wisely chosen, and all the actors do a competent job in lending their voice & soul to the mammals they play. Ginnifer Goodwin brings a bubbly side to the new cop in town and confidently plays her role. Jason Bateman plays his part with finesse plus his voice really fits his cynical con artist character. Also, the chemistry between the two is a highlight in itself. Michael Giacchino's ebullient score seamlessly blends in & compliments the narrative while Shakira beautifully wraps everything up with a catchy, uplifting & wonderful song that smartly summarises its themes & message. On an overall scale, Zootopia finds Disney stepping out of its comfort zone to tackle a bold, ambitious & risky project, and it is one gamble that pays off tremendously well in the studio's favour. Also, its arrival couldn't have been better, considering how its elements of prejudice & stereotypes mirror the racial hostilities present in our very own current social environment. An ingenious blend of sophisticated storytelling, jubilant humour & thought-provoking themes that amazes, entertains & enlightens without ever compromising with the fun factor, Zootopia is a definite delight for viewers of all ages, and is undoubtedly the best film of the year, so far. Strongly recommended.

comment: Normally I enjoy animated films because they're are usually visually stunning and that is enough to hold my attention. Some I love and some I just enjoy even if they are flawed. But I was fairly excited for this film so I watched it, because I'm a sucker for animated films, and I was absolutely blown away by this movie and it surpassed my expectations. Firstly, Zootropolis (or Zootopia depending where you come from) is much, much more than your generic Disney film. It will actually entertain a higher age demographic rather than younger kids due to it's exciting story and mature themes and because it is more a crime drama than a comedy. Yes, the directors and writers aren't afraid to explore much more darker and mature themes then they usually do and they do throw in a few jump worthy parts. On the other hand, the kids will probably enjoy seeing the animals speak but adults will be really engaged because of it's story. This film definitely deserved it's Academy Award Oscar for 'Best Animated Feature'. Secondly, this film had me hooked all the way through because of its detective and mysterious themes and its crime drama story, it's frequently humourous sequences and because the film had a surprising amount of an emotional weight towards it. Even though the tone is normally dark for an animated Disney film, the film still allows for some hilarious moments that, luckily, doesn't affect the overall tone. And like all modern Disney films, this film has stunning backdrops and top-notch animation and the soundtrack isn't half bad, either, alongside side it's exciting score. Furthermore, Zootropolis works well because of it's extremely likeable characters, who have emotional and sympathetic backstories, it's story, which is well paced, extremely well told and presented, and as the chemistry between Nick Wilde and Judy Hopps is rich and compelling because of it's well written dialogue and great casting choices including Idris Elba, Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman. Not only that but Zootropolis thrills in it's tension filled action sequences and due to it's shocking plot twists; Zootropolis also allows Godfather fans to be delighted as well. In the end, Zootropolis isn't your average animated film because it is much more than that, it has an extremely intriguing, unprecedented presence and a well told story and is aided by compelling characters and fun moments. Zootropolis not only sets a bar high for future animated films but is probably one the best animated films ever made as of 2016. Additionally, Zootropolis is also one of the most enjoyable family films ever made. I absolutely adore Zootropolis.

comment: Zootropolis (Zootopia) was a part of my highly anticipated list of movies for this year. Sure, Deadpool looked amazing (and was, according to nearly everyone) and Batman V Superman was the NEXT BIG THING but there was just something about Zootropolis that made me so excited. After reviews started rolling in, it got me even more excited, Chris Stuckmann's review especially. (Link at the bottom of review) And now I finally got to watch it. And I can simply say that Zootropolis was...AMAZING! Oh by the way, this review is SPOILER FREE. The Story Zootropolis's story is about a passionate little bunny known as Judy Hopps. She wants to do good for the world and decides that she wants to be a cop. This isn't very common and many of the other animals show that but Judy thinks that everyone can be whoever they want to be. When she has her first case, she isn't given much so she teams up with a fox known as Nick Wilde to help her solve the case. I really like this story as Nick and Judy get to learn more about each other throughout the story and as well as that, it results in a really fun, family adventure. The Characters Oh my the characters. In my opinion, this is Zootropolis's strongest parts. They are just so likeable! And before I talk about them, I have to talk about how well the actors portray them. I think Ginnifer Goodwin did a brilliant job at voicing Judy and I haven't seen many movies with Jason Bateman as a voice of a character or a character but I think he did an excellent job as Nick. And I can't forget Idris Elba's performance as Chief Bogo (the one who gives out the cases) He nailed it. Alright, now what I thought about them. Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde steal the show completely. (well, they are the main characters)They both have strengths and weaknesses which show throughout the movie a lot and they do have some really funny, touching and quite crazy moments that I will not spoil. And even though Chief Bogo is that character who can be a bit of a jerk at the beginning, you come to see him from a different perspective when the movie goes on. There are many more characters that do a really good job but this section is already too big. On to the animation. The Animation As usual, Disney did a great job with the animation. The action scenes look great, the visuals are fantastic and the city itself is huge. I may now sound like i'm doing a video game review but i'm not. The city is beautiful with flying colors. (quite literally actually) So yeah, they did a really good job, as usual. The Comedy If you watch Chris Stuckmann's Review, he says that: "It is more focused on it's story then making you laugh. And that's something I loved about it." And I agree. I think the story is brilliant and because of it, when the jokes come up, there actually hilarious. The comedy is focused around children and adults so of course, there will be jokes where only the adults will laugh or only the children. According to other reviewers, the scene with "Mr Big" was paying homage to: "The Godfather." And even though I haven't seen The Godfather, the whole scene was really funny. This goes to show you what you're going to expect. And here's the final part of the review... The Serious Note/ The Message Now is when I talk to you about the serious note. This movie focuses on so many different subjects you don't think a Disney movie would ever cover. I actually quite like it because it adds a little more originality to it. If you have ever watched Happy Feet, it was trying to deliver a message. But the way they did was so childlike that it made it pointless for older kids or adults. But Zootopia did it with a more serious tone and a non forceful way that it really delivered it well. The Grade I love Zootropolis. It's message is brought well, it's animation is great, it's characters are awesome, it's comedy is hilarious, it's story is brilliant and it's serious tone makes it even better. This movie is defiantly 100% worth watching and i'm going to give it an A+ Chris Stuckmann's Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Du7wcFPBfIE

comment: Zootopia is the 30th highest grossing film of all time, and the fourth animated film to pass $1 billion in global box-office earnings. Judy Hopps, the determined and enthusiastic main character, decides she wants better for herself, even when something else is expected. She faces many hardships as she realizes that creating a different reality for herself will be a lot harder than she first believed. Her difficulties point to the fact that she is a female, and a smaller prey species. In the end, Judy is successful in creating the change that she had been wanting for so long. Zootopia was created to teach people of all ages that goals and dreams can be reached through hard work and determination, no matter what circumstances they may be in. The directors were successful in getting the point across. This essay will analyze the use of irony, symbolism, and a great storyline to show evidence of the creators purpose throughout the film. The directors of Zootopia waste no time in presenting situational irony in the beginning. The main characters are introduced, and we meet Judy Hopps. She is a small bunny with a very large family, and two carrot farmers for parents. She is literally at the "bottom of the food chain" in her society. The ironic part of the situation is that she wants to become a police officer. In her world, this workforce is comprised only of large male animals. The creators do this to immediately place her in a position where she is at a disadvantage. To the viewers, her wish to become a cop is almost comical, and the task seems impossible because of her situation. In the end, however, Judy does become a police officer. She not only becomes a cop, she ends up being one of the most successful ones who solves a huge mystery case. The overall story is a testament that if Judy can turn her life around, anyone can. Symbolism is also included in the movie, and it is one of the most powerful tools used in the film to convey the creator's purpose. The characters present in the movie represent many different types of people in the real world. The wide variety of animal species shown in the film are meant to represent the different races, social classes, intelligence levels, etc.., that are present in today's world. The directors do this to give viewers the ability to connect with certain characters that they might be similar to in reality. This is meant to empower the minds of young viewers as they watch the actions of the characters that they connect with. They see them working hard to set goals, and successfully achieve them. This leaves people with a healthy mindset and a hope that they can always better themselves, no matter the circumstances. The overall story itself is another way the point is made. Judy's life and work are anything but easy, and she is constantly dealing with new challenges. comment: I didn't know what to think about this movie before I saw it. There was so much hype I was afraid to be disappointed. All I knew was that it was highly anticipated, and when it came out people went crazy for it. Critics and audiences alike loved this movie for being "real," and coming out at "just the right time in America." This was mainly due to the fact that film talks a lot about race, while not talking directly about race. You see, it's like Paddington, Babar, or Curious George in that way. It talks about race, but only through animals. So it's not actually portraying people of color, but using anthropomorphic creatures to do so. The movie would have been so much more effective if they animated people of color and the institutions which keep white people privileged. But they don't. Instead it's incredibly confusing when it comes to who are the haves, and who are the have nots. They may have done this to be ambiguous in order to show that many people are intersectional, but because they're animals, it doesn't really work that way. Like do black sheep have different standards and societal expectations than white sheep? The animal allegory doesn't work unless they're all the same animal because it literally shows us that races are different species (eugenics), when that isn't true. Lastly, you can map out the plot from a mile away. So let's dive into the good, the bad and the ugly, with Zootopia. Very simply put, the movie is about a rabbit and a fox. The rabbit, named Judy, wants to be a cop. But because she's a prey animal and also a woman - they don't really address gender that much, but for the sake of this review, I will - she's not supposed to be a cop, she's supposed to remain a little farm bunny. But like most Disney female characters she wants more than "this provincial life," so she moves to Zootopia, a utopian city where prey and predator live together in harmony. This of course isn't true as Judy soon finds out. She faces prejudice as a prey animal at work and in the city, but decides to take her destiny in her own paws. She tackles a huge who done it mystery case and teams up with a criminal fox, Nick, and the unlikely duo solves the crime. The villain (spoilers) turns out to be a white sheep, a seemingly innocent prey animal. All in all, the moral is, looks can be deceiving, and anyone can be whatever they want to be, no matter what society says. I love the land of Zootopia. I think it's so creative how they make a Sahara part, a jungle part, a tundra part, and even a tiny rodent village. That's awesome! But aside from a few scenes, they don't really show much of the city. I also don't like how the animal allegory has so many plot holes. And this is mainly because the movie uses animals instead of people! Lastly, Shakira and Judy are constantly sexualized. The villain is obvious and the movie is long. Sitting through the misunderstanding between Nick and Judy was agonizing. So, the racial allegory, does it do its job? No. I was constantly confused in the movie if they were trying to confirm that reverse racism exists. Sometimes it seemed as though the prey were the people of color and the predators were white. This happens when Nick tries touching the sheep's hair and Judy says, "You know you can't just touch a sheep's wool." This is obviously mimicking real life, when you can't just go up and touch a black person's hair. Sometimes it makes it seem as though it's the other way around, and the prey are white and the people of color are predators. What the f*ck? This can be seen when the prey animals are trying to "civilize" the predators. The predators are thugs and "black." This can be seen with the jaguar who goes "savage" because savagery is a trait put on African Americans as well as indigenous people. So does that mean the prey is white and the people of color are predators? Maybe they're saying that the white people (prey) are actually the savages and taking a Pocahontas/Paddington route? I just don't know. And that's a problem because if the movie is going for a racial allegory, then it has to be clear. But instead it's muddled because Disney was too afraid to use people, so they used cute little animals to tell their "progressive" story. I also didn't like the comedic elements in the film. There was the nudist thing. Was that supposed to be funny? Animals not wearing clothes, ha-ha? Then The Godfather references were meh. It's been done before. Then of course you have the Disney/Pixar trope of juxtaposing an animal's size with the type of voice it has. In Zootopia, there's a small animal with a deep voice. It's similar to Up with the evil dog having a high pitched voice, or the cute baby form The Incredibles who is actually the devil. I'm TIRED OF IT. The other problematic part I have with the film is the sexualization of animals. I know they're supposed to be anthropomorphic and take on human qualities. But really, we're going give a bunny boobs and hips? We're going to sexualize Giselle -Shakira's character - by having the camera hold on her animal butt uncomfortably? These are animals! They're not sexy. Well, maybe they are to some people, but it's also adding to the sexualization of female characters. The men are not sexualized the same way the women are. In fact, the men are able to have a wide range of body types, while the females are given very little. But as for the main characters, Judy's body is much more "feminine" than Nick's. Nick just looks like a fox on his hind legs, but Judy is given curves, why, if not to titillate the presumably straight men watching it. I guess if I had to say something I liked about the film, it would have to be my favorite scene. I love the part where Judy is spying on Nick and discovers his undercover Popsicle scheme. It's really cool seeing different parts of the city, how his life works, and the different animals he meets. Nick, unlike Judy, rolls with his stereotype as the "sly fox." But this brings me to another problem, some animals fit into their stereotypes while others don't. Why is this? To create a wide range of characters, or for comedic effect? comment: "Disney: Hilariously Exploiting Stereotypes In Animal Form" Who would have thought that another Disney animation focused on the lives of animals would be such a hit? If you want to laugh, cry, be uplifted, and experience a myriad of emotions, then Zootopia is the movie for you. Kids will love the cute animals depicted throughout the movie, as well as childish humor that kids will giggle hysterically at. Moreover, adults will not struggle with keeping their attention focused on the movie, like most "Kid" movies, because of the amazing artistry and captivating plot. An astounding feat that the film accomplished is the teaching opportunity it took to discuss, for all ages, real world issues that we struggle with around the world today. From the tiny stature of a mob boss arctic shrew, Mr. Big, to the largest elephant yoga teacher, the metropolis of Zootopia is a place thought to be where all types of animals can live, thrive, and make their dreams come true. This is the case for a small town bunny name Judy Hopps (wonderfully voiced by Ginnifer Goodwin). Judy a determined and peppy rabbit with the inability to stop pursuing her dreams becomes the first bunny police officer in Zootopia. With the odds stacked against her, Officer Hopps takes on a curious case that will make or break her dreams and the metropolis of Zootopia. On her quest, Judy pairs up with an unimaginable partner, a con artist fox named Nick Wilde (brilliantly voiced by Jason Bateman). Together the unthinkable partners have to piece together clues to solve the mysterious case that could prove to be the end of the marvelous metropolis of Zootopia. The amazing plot of the movie takes on the difficult task to teach its viewers the complexities and blatant issues of the world that may or may not be easily noticed. For example, two true enemies in the animal kingdom, a fox and bunny, have to set aside their differences to make sure that their metropolis survives. How is this any different in the real human world today? One can take many approaches to this issue such as Republicans and Democrats working together, high-income citizens cooperating and working with low-income citizens, black and white Americans working together, and many other real life scenarios that cause conflict in the world. This issue between Nick Wilde and Judy Hopps teaches us that we have a choice to who we are and we can put aside our differences and work together harmoniously. A particular point in the film that demonstrated the stroke of genius from the directors is the incorporation of the DMV run by sloths. It is common knowledge that sloths are some of the slowest moving creatures on earth, and the DMV is one of the most frustrating government agencies because of their slothful nature in dealing with customers. This hilarious and outrageous portrayal in which officer Hopps has to struggle with a sluggish sloth when she is in a hurry to get pertinent information dealing with her case gives a classic representation of real world frustration that many have undergone. The simple yet complex features throughout the movie provide a stimulating and relatable story. As the movie progresses, an underlying issue is finally revealed that will shock the audience. The issue brought to light is that sometimes the real threat to an individual or society is not the predator in the relationship, but the conniving prey. The movie teaches us that we need to put our prejudices aside so we can make correct decisions based on actual evidence, rather than viewing things through biased lenses. This is a powerful message that is placed in the movie that demonstrates the calamity in the world, especially in the United States, because of previous historical issues that will not be put to rest. Directors Bryon Howard, Richard Moore, and Jared Bush put their minds together to create a unique reality in which animals endure the same small and large concerns that humans do. Some of which include dirty politics, racism, and the struggle to live harmoniously with people of all backgrounds. This fascinating parallel between skin color and animal variety shares a beautiful angle on the diversity of the world. With their creative perspective, the directors flawlessly incorporated other iconic films into Zootopia such as "The Godfather", "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", and many other classic films. This tasteful placement of themes of iconic films adds a subtle complexity that made the movie enjoyable to all age ranges. Walt Disney productions over the past few years have been impeccable, including Big Hero Six, Tangled, and the widely popular Frozen. Individuals that have seen these films understand the amazing results that all these movies have achieved, but many would conclude that they have reached the peak of their performance. These conclusions couldn't be more wrong because Zootopia is Disney's true masterpiece. comment: I can think of no other film that is as timely as this one. Though it's a typical Disney film in structure, the entire film is an overt allegory for racism... and how we each can do our part to overcome prejudice and adversity in society. The protagonist is little Judy Hopps, who aspires to become a police officer despite her diminutive bunny stature and country-bumpkin background. Judy is a great protagonist and worthy role model for little girls, or anybody really. The weird thing about her, and what makes this movie so different, is that she's a racist. She doesn't want to be, and tries very hard not to be, and the story follows her as she begins to realize her prejudices and works to overcome them. The overall message of inclusion and celebrating diversity is a timely and important one, and one that has never been so fully expressed in a children's film. The movie touches on some pretty sensitive racial and gender stereotypes, including some not-so-disguised Islamophobia. I said to myself "Damn, I can't believe they went there" more than once. So yeah, it does get a little heavy for a Disney film, but there is enough humor and action mixed in to lighten up the subject matter. comment: Zootopia (2016) - Has made a huge impact on a lot of people and at first I never understood why. I never thought the movie was going to be bad but I just didn't think that this would be the next big thing for Disney especially after their amazing lineup of films like "Tangled" and "Big Hero 6". However, when I finally saw the movie I was completely blown away and now I see why everyone loves this film so much. There were two things that stood out to me, one of them was the chemistry between Judy and Nick. They are probably one of the most irresistible Disney pairings since Rapunzel and Flynn Rider. I really loved the way they work off of each other as well as warming up to share their feelings. The other thing I loved is the way they establish the city of Zootopia itself. Through a clever use of imagery we see how Predators and Prey became what they are today. We also see the many districts that Zootopia has to offer and they take full advantage of showing of each and every one of them and how unique they are. The other part of the story includes a mystery that our heroes have to crack. The mystery only keeps getting bigger and bigger as the movie plays on and the places they visit all have a critical importance into bringing our characters closer to the final reveal. The side characters they meet along the way all have their memorable moments and some of them play important roles into cracking the case. The big thing that caught many people's attention was the morals of Racism and discrimination against others. It does go pretty deep when telling those messages and hits a homerun for a lot of people. I think the way they use Predator and Prey to teach that moral is genius and leads to a lot of heartfelt moments that did make me feel emotional from time to time. The animation is mind blowing and they capture the feeling of being in a big city while also adding features like size and scope to make Zootopia feel so universal to any size of mammal. The characters also look very Disney and it's very cool how each one of them is accurately sized like their real life counterparts. The music was done by Michael Giacchino. You may recognize him as the composer for many Pixar films like "Ratatouille" and "Inside out". The music features a lot of electric guitar beats and bass strums which really help embrace the feeling of big city life. Theres also a featured pop song by Shakira called "Try Everything" and it plays itself out as an inspirational song that really does fit the movie's theme and everything it stands for. My only nitpick would have to be the pace of the third act. It doesn't ruin anything and it's done great in terms of the story, but I felt like after coming off everything that happened in the 2nd act, it just felt a little off when things start to come back to together. Overall, I was surprised by this movie and it's probably one of the best that Disney has to offer. (A)

comment: Zootopia: Bunny Cop to the Rescue Zootopia: Disney's best animated movie of 2016 is full of cheerful, courageous, and slightly disapproving characters who take you on a remarkable journey to save their beloved city, Zootopia. Early in the movie when Judy is seeing Zootopia for the first time you get an impression of what Zootopia really is. A city where racism does not exist and where diversity is accepted. Zootopia is the place where both predators and prey have evolved past their natural desire to kill each other and live in grace. Its charm results from the spectacular animation and witty script. Judy Hopps (perfectly voiced by Gennifer Goodwin) is a bunny who has her mind set on becoming the first female cop and move to the big city of Zootopia where she presumes to be just like the big city cops. Judy, who lives in a farm with her 275 brothers and sisters, gets no support from her parents who want her to stay and help build their business, but Judy, listening to her heart, follows her dreams. She goes through strenuous training and her hard work pays off because she finishes top of her class and she quickly decides to put her skills to good use and moves to the big city of Zootopia. She is immediately struck with the brutal truth of adult life where she has a depressing apartment. Judy reports to work and quickly becomes frustrated. No one takes her seriously because she is a tiny bunny. On her very first day she is assigned traffic duty. Her boss, Chief Bogo (Idris Elba) clearly has no faith in her and even shows signs of regrets when it came to hiring a female bunny. However that doesn't stop Judy Hopps. This film demonstrates that even when the world wants you to fail, if you believe in yourself you can achieve anything. This is why Zootopia is one of the best Disney movies ever made. When Judy is finally presented with a real case she has to uncover the truth behind the mysterious disappearance of mammals all over the city. She only has one clue though, a cunning fox named Nick (voice of Jason Bateman). The two set out on a wild, bizarre, dangerous mission to find out what is happening to the mammals of Zootopia. The film nailed the chemistry between Judy and Nick specifically when they find themselves in danger when they search for a paranoid and ominous panther named Mr. Manchas (voice by Jesse Corti). You just know that even when the movie takes some dark turns, nothing will separate the two. Zootopia demonstrates the values of true friendship and what teamwork can accomplish, as well as displaying what courage, faith, and commitment accomplish if you never give up. Furthermore, there is no targeted audience with this film because anyone at any age could benefit from watching a movie like this. The length of the movie is long enough to include all the details necessary and not leave people baffled because of unanswered questions. Another strong aspect of the film was the incredibly talented animation which included a touch of realism throughout the whole film and it did not go unnoticed since it won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature. It's very much demonstrated with the features of the city and with the many different animal species, particularly when Judy was saying goodbye to her family and we get a glimpse of all of her siblings. Zootopia may not have the single alongs that Frozen has, but it's clever enough to catch your attention when personal resilience is so well demonstrated and captures your emotions so well. It conveys a message that are rarely seen in movies for children:Success is no accident. It's hard work, studying, learning, sacrifice and love for what you are doing.

comment: Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin lend their voices in Disney's Zootopia. Zootopia is an area where all animals are able to live together in harmony. Goodwin is Judy Hoops, a young rabbit that has aspirations to be a cop. She is of course ridiculed as rabbits are typical farmers that are not aggressive. She aims high and graduates from school only to become stereotyped again by her Water buffalo boss (Idris Elba) who makes her become a meter maid. To demonstrate that she can offer more to the force, she takes on a missing otter case and agrees to solve the case within 48 hours or quit. With few leads and evidence, she has no choice but to have a cunning fox Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman) help her even though foxes are known for being mischievous and untrustworthy. As she investigates the case, she finds there is a strange occurrence where historical predators are becoming savage again. The She adds this mystery to the case and hopes to return Zootopia and make it safe for all animals again. Zootopia is above average animated film. The film offers enough humor for adults and the animation will likely dazzle young audiences alike. Many jokes rely on animals being stereotyped such as sloths for being slow and foxes being cunning. Bateman does a good job providing his sense of humor that will be appreciated by fans of his. Puns such as we need to address the elephant in the room, and there being a literal elephant in the room are also scattered throughout the film. Various films such as the Godfather are also parodied. The film does not have as clever or an original premise such as some of the other Pixar films. The concept of a bunch of different animals together seemed all too similar to the many Madagascar films made. As with many Disney films there is an overall good message to leave with the audience, and this one is to always believe in yourself and dreams, and to not judge a book (or an animal) by its cover. The film is well animated, but does not dazzle or leave one in awe. Although there is nothing particularly wrong or glaring with Zootopia, in the sea of animated films that are becoming more and more popular, Disney's Zootopia does not stand out as much as I had hoped. The film is a general crowd pleaser that does not take much risk and simply tries to entertain and that's not always a bad thing. -2.9.2017

comment: There's been alot of buzz surrounding this movie. All year, in fact. People seem to be attracted to this movie because of it's themes of racism, despite it being a "family adventure film". I wonder why that is? Firstly, I find this film to be immensely overrated. It sits on a 98% on Rotten Tomatoes and it seems to be that Zootopia is impossible to hate. Admittedly, it is a great children's film and a movie that adults will also enjoy, and critics seem to agree. This does *not* mean, however, it is a perfect or near-perfect movie. The biggest flaw in Zootopia is that it tries to be a family film, with an underlying theme of racism and prejudice beneath the surface. The problem is, the film lacks a sense of subtlety. This means that the film tries to have its carrot and eat it, giving a lack of focus and a less-than-great performance in each of the areas. The film would have gone better if it had a sense of subtlety but prefers to heighten the mystery just enough to go over kids heads. Another animated movie about the personification of animals, "Fantastic Mr. Fox" managed to nail the balance by using the characters and the theme to build off each other The main character's in Zootopia, a rabbit named Judy Hopps and a fox named Nick Wilde, were the only properly fleshed out characters in the movie. While this makes sense for a buddy-cop film (like this movie is, whether you like it or not) it does not work when you are trying to build a universe, which arguably is one of this film's biggest priorities. Though the chemistry (no pun intended) between the protagonists is quite charming, the other characters are animal-themed cardboard cutouts of what you've already seen before. This film could have been more ambitious with its ideas and message, however it chooses to focus on its main priorities, almost like a movie check-list that needs to be completed. The story, like the character's, and unfortunately quite cliched and mediocre, which is a real shame as I find the setting quite interesting and creative. It makes sense that this would be the case, however like the characters, it too would have benefited in being more interesting and ambitious. The progression is just what you'd expect from a film of the buddy-cop variety and the editing is just fine, though the twist at the end, which I'm not going to spoil, can be seen from a mile off. Zootopia is a fine, if conventional, animated movie that unfortunately tries a little too hard to be something it's not. Despite all the criticism's I've given it, it still has all the infectious Disney charm that we've come to know and love. Though the characters and story is somewhat cliched, it is built upon and built upon quite well. Kids are gonna love it anyway and adults will probably still enjoy it. All-in-all, 7/10.

comment: I may be the last person on the planet to have finally watched Zootopia, Disney's first quarter hit of the year, and I am very glad that I did. I was expecting something cute with the premise of a plucky rabbit (voiced winningly by Ginnfer Goodwin) joining forces with a wily grifter fox (Jason Bateman) in the big animal metropolis, but what I wasn't expecting was a fully thought out and stupendously imaginative world and a message that is just as thought out and pertinent. The anthropomorphic animal land is filled with colorful locations and plenty of amusing characters. It's highly amusing just to sit back and watch. I knew I was in for something radically different and dare I say more ambitious when there was an N-word approximation joke within the first ten minutes. This was not a moving to be taken lying down. My attention was rewarded with an engaging relationship between the two leads, careful plotting, endlessly clever asides without relying upon an inordinate amount of pop-culture references, and ultimately a noble and relevant message about the power of inclusion, tolerance, and rejecting prejudice. The larger metaphor seems slightly muddied by the late reveal of who is behind the conspiracy to make the animals go feral, but I wouldn't say it undercuts the film's power. The characters charmed me and I was happy that each ecosystem factored into the story in fun and interesting ways. There are plenty of payoffs distributed throughout the movie to make it even more rewarding. comment: Judy Hopps is a young rabbit with dreams of one day becoming a police officer. No rabbit has ever been a police officer, but Judy perseveres and succeeds. Now she is off to Zootopia, a multi-animal society where all animals, predator and prey, live in harmony. Her euphoria and idealism is short-lived, however, as she discovers that prejudice between species still exists, and she even starts to doubt her anti-stereotyping stance. What's more, she's assigned to parking meter duty... Wonderfully original. The idea of animals harmoniously coexisting in one world, and essentially representing characters that humans would usually take, on has been done (Jungle Book, Robin Hood) but to this extent. Some great little in-jokes and use of the different characteristics of the different animals. Nice story too, with some very engaging plots and characters. Some clever pop-cultural references too (eg The Godfather, Breaking Bad). Behind it all is a great anti-prejudice, anti-racism message which is conveyed very effectively. Maybe a little too effectively in that it is laid on a bit thick and comes across as preachy. A bit more subtlety was in order, though, for kids, the target demographic of the movie, the level was probably about right. Voice casting is spot on, with a host of stars contributing: Ginnifer Goodwin, Jason Bateman, Idris Elba, Tommy Chong (as a stoner, of course!), JK Simmons, Octavia Spencer, Alan Tudyk, Shakira, Bonnie Hunt.
